item.title: Need help in C++ Homework (1)
item.dc:creator: @reVein reVein
item.description:
@reVein wrote:

rifk, “void main()” isn’t used anymore, neither is the .h end in iostream because it gives you a warning about sstream or some other shit + that program wouldn’t work because you need to add “using namespace std;” or add std:: infront of every cout, cin, and endl.

[code=cpp]#include
#include

using namespace std;

int main()
{
float sec;
char out = 12345;
char rifk = 1;

cout << "Multiprogram\n";
cout << "------------\n";
cout << "Part 1)\n";
cout << "-------\n";
cout << "Enter seconds: ";
cin >> sec;
cout << sec/3600 << " hours, " << sec/60 << " minutes and " << sec << " seconds.\n";
cout << "-------\n";
cout << "Part 2)\n";
cout << "-------\n";
cout << "If you assign 12345 to a char variable, it will output this: *" << out << "*\nbecause char only accepts one character or a small integer\n";
cout << "Other numbers in char will give you strange symbols, such as a smiley like this one: " << rifk << endl << endl;
system("PAUSE");

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Need help in C++ Homework (1)
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“Kevin3654, post:1, topic:232694”]Write programs to do the following

Input an integer representing seconds from the user and convert it into hours, minutes, and seconds. Use / and %. a.Assign the integer 12345 into a character variable. What warning does the compiler give you, and what is the output when you print the character? Why doesn't the same value print as a character and an integer? [/quote]
Maybe later.

What is the value assigned to v3 in the following program? Why? [code]#include void main() { int v1=7, v2=5, v3=0; v3=v1* (v2=6); cout << v3 << endl; }[/code]
v3 = 7*(6) = 42. The value of v2 is reassigned during the calculation. (To be honest, I'm not sure if the C++ syntax allows this, so somebody confirm?)
Why doesn't the following program compile? (explain the error message)

#include <iostream.h> void main() { int v1=7, v2=5, v3=0; v3=v1 * v2=6; cout << v3 << endl; }


Well there’s a couple of things (in my opinion). For one, you cannot assign a value to a variable the way they did in this snippet (confirm?). Another (possibly): the main method is supposed to return type int.
What is the output of this program? Why? [code]#include void main() { int stop = 0; while (stop = 0) { int blah; cout << "Give a value " <> blah; if (blah > 17) stop = 1; } }[/code]
Give a value (user input: 18) HALT

Actually, the output varies on what you input. If the value is greater than 17, then it halts. If its less than 17, it just continously asks you for input starting with “GIve a value”.

Correct the errors in the following program [code]#include void main() int sum= value=0; char stop = 'n'; cout <> n; for (int i = 0; i <=n && stop='n', i++) { cout << input integer (i+1) <> value; sum += value; cout << "The sum so far is " << sum << " Do you want to stop now?(y/n)" << endl <> stop; if (stop == 'n') then i = n; } cout << "The final sum is " << sum << endl; [/code]

Thanks

->

#include <iostream.h> void main() { int sum, value=0; char stop = 'n'; cout << "Give an integer for n, the number of values you will input\n"; int n; cin >> n; for (int i = 0; i <= n && stop='n', i++) { cout << i << endl; cin >> value; sum += value; cout << "The sum so far is " << sum << " Do you want to stop now?(y/n)" << endl <<; cin >> stop; if (stop == "n") i = 'n'; } cout << "The final sum is " << sum << endl; }

P.S. I’m not really into C++ or anything, and don’t know much about it, but this is using my basic knowledge in the area of C++ and my more-experienced-ness in Java. So keep in mind I may have gotten the syntax wrong or data types/conversions wrong as I’m used to Java. But hey, I felt like giving it a go. It’s also YOUR assignment not mine, and if you’re taking the class, you should’ve learned all this by now. So next time, LEARN IT.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help in C++ Homework (1)
item.dc:creator: @Kevin3654 Kevin3654
item.description:
@Kevin3654 wrote:

Hey im kinda having trouble with these.
I would appreciate some help.

CSCI 175: C++ Homework 1

Write programs to do the following

Input an integer representing seconds from the user and convert it into hours, minutes, and seconds. Use / and %. a.Assign the integer 12345 into a character variable. What warning does the compiler give you, and what is the output when you print the character? Why doesn't the same value print as a character and an integer?

What is the value assigned to v3 in the following program? Why?

#include <iostream.h> void main() { int v1=7, v2=5, v3=0; v3=v1* (v2=6); cout << v3 << endl; }
Why doesn’t the following program compile? (explain the error message)

#include <iostream.h> void main() { int v1=7, v2=5, v3=0; v3=v1 * v2=6; cout << v3 << endl; }
What is the output of this program? Why?

#include <iostream.h> void main() { int stop = 0; while (stop = 0) { int blah; cout << "Give a value " << endl; cin >> blah; if (blah > 17) stop = 1; } }
Correct the errors in the following program

#include <iostream.h> void main() int sum= value=0; char stop = 'n'; cout << "Give an integer for n, the number of values you will input\n"; int n; cin >> n; for (int i = 0; i <=n && stop='n', i++) { cout << input integer (i+1) << endl; cin >> value; sum += value; cout << "The sum so far is " << sum << " Do you want to stop now?(y/n)" << endl <<; cin >> stop; if (stop == 'n') then i = n; } cout << "The final sum is " << sum << endl;

Thanks

Read full topic
